argumentText:
*1.* Let $X$ be a martingale. By the optional sampling theorem we have
$E(X_c|\mathcal{F}_{\tau}) = X_{c \wedge \tau} = X_{\tau} \forall \tau \leq c$.
Since conditional expectations are uniformly integrable the first
direction follows.

*2.* Let $(\tau_k)_{k \geq 1}$ be a local sequence of stopping times
(i.e. $\tau_k \uparrow \infty$ a.s. and $X^{\tau_k}$ martingale
$\forall k \in \mathbb{N}$). For each $t \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$ we have
$X_{\tau_k \wedge t} \to X_t, k \to \infty$ almost surely. The set
$$\begin{aligned}
\{X_{\tau_k \wedge t} : k \in \mathbb{N}\} &\subset \{X_{\tau} : \tau \ \text{stopping time}, \tau \leq c\}\end{aligned}$$

is uniformly integrable (take $c = t$). It follows that
$X_t^{\tau_k} \stackrel{\substack{\mathscr{L}^1}}{\longrightarrow} X_t, k \to \infty$.
Since the martingale property is stable under $\mathscr{L}^1$
convergence, $X$ is a martingale.
